Colonial Terminals Operating Company LLC (CTOC), d/b/a Colonial Pipeline Terminals (CPT), owns a butane blending system located at 7720 Mt. Holly Road, Charlotte, North Carolina. The

Charlotte Terminal Butane Blending System was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) #58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes. It is the intent of the Charlotte Terminal to incorporate the most recent construction and procedural guidance (NFPA # 58-2011 Edition) into this process. If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Charlotte Fire Department as well as the Charlotte/Mecklenburg County Department of Emergency Management. Medical emergencies will require notification of the local Emergency Medical Services ("Medic").



The CPT Charlotte Terminal is a bulk petroleum storage and distribution facility that includes butane blending operations. This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane blending system, including the associated piping and two butane storage vessels.



The CPT Charlotte Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) along with its fourteen (14) compliance elements, and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer.



This is an existing system; however, this facility has never had an accident involving the butane process which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.



In the event of an emergency involving the CPT Charlotte Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the facility to initial

ly contact the Charlotte Fire Department (Primary Responder) and request their assistance. The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with fire department and the Charlotte/Mecklenburg County Department of Emergency Management. The Charlotte Fire Department has participated in the initial RMP/PSM training session for this system.



Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point fusible links to excess flow valves (fail closed), emergency shut-off devices on the system, line thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding devices.



In an effort to improve and promote system safety, CPT looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. Additionally, the Charlotte Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills.
